gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: larval krill pigments from the SOGLOBEC project of the U.S. GLOBEC program

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Southern Ocean larval krill studies- fluorescence and clearance, 2001-2002 Dataset Description: <p>"Winter ecology of larval krill: quatifying their interaction with the pack ice habitat"</p><p>The goal of the larval krill studies was to investigate the physiology and ecology of krill larvae associated with the pack ice and the microbial community on which they feed.</p><p>During LMG0106 we occupied two 4-5 day ice stations (Robert and Billy) and sampled several other ice floes opportunistically. We conducted 10 instantaneous growth rate experiments, and 4 whole body clearance time experiments to determine gut passage time (decline in pigment content over time). We also sampled larvae at two additional sites for initial body pigment content (whole body fluorescence), and at 4 sites for condition factor. The under-ice algal community was sampled at one site. Length and stage frequency determinations were also determined.</p><p>We occupied three time-series stations of approximately 1 week each, and in addition opportunistically sampled at times when other activities had priority. Our primary goal during the cruise was to occupy three ice camps or process stations with the intent of thoroughly studying the under-ice environment by SCUBA in conjunction with other projects working topside. <a href="http://www.ccpo.odu.edu/Research/globec/main_cruises02/lmg0205/report_lmg0205.pdf" target="_blank"><em>(from cruise report LMG0205)</em></a></p> Acquisition Description: <p>Using SCUBA techniques allowed us to collect larval krill as close as possible to their in situ condition. Larval krill were collected for time-based experimentation at the dive hole, for shipboard experiments and preserved for later analysis. Samples of the micro-zooplankton community were sampled with suction samplers to gain a better understanding of food available to the larvae relative to their distribution under the ice. In addition, at one of the process stations we were able to deploy drift nets through the dive holes to compare day/night differences in the zooplankton community at depths of 1 m and 10 m below the ice-water interface. <a href="http://www.ccpo.odu.edu/Research/globec/main_cruises02/lmg0205/report_lmg0205.pdf" target="_blank"><em>(from cruise report LMG0205)</em></a></p>

gmd:credit.gmx:Anchor: Funding provided by NSF Antarctic Sciences (NSF ANT) Award Number: ANT-9909933 Award URL: http://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward.do?AwardNumber=9909933

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: none. Use Constraints: Please follow guidelines at: http://www.bco-dmo.org/terms-use Distribution liability: Under no circumstances shall BCO-DMO be liable for any direct, incidental, special, consequential, indirect, or punitive damages that result from the use of, or the inability to use, the materials in this data submission. If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: U.S. GLOBEC (GLOBal ocean ECosystems dynamics) is a research program organized by oceanographers and fisheries scientists to address the question of how global climate change may affect the abundance and production of animals in the sea.The U.S. GLOBEC Program currently had major research efforts underway in the Georges Bank / Northwest Atlantic Region, and the Northeast Pacific (with components in the California Current and in the Coastal Gulf of Alaska). U.S. GLOBEC was a major contributor to International GLOBEC efforts in the Southern Ocean and Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP).

The fundamental objectives of United StatesGlobal Ocean Ecosystems Dynamics (U.S. GLOBEC) Program are dependent upon thecooperation of scientists from several disciplines. Physicists, biologists, andchemists must make use of data collected during U.S. GLOBEC field programs tofurther our understanding of the interplay of physics, biology, and chemistry.Our objectives require quantitative analysis of interdisciplinary data setsand, therefore, data must be exchanged between researchers. To extract the fullscientific value, data must be made available to the scientific community on atimely basis.

http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20860.rdf Name: cruiseid Units: text Description: cruise identification
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20861.rdf Name: year Units: YYYY Description: year of experiment
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20862.rdf Name: sample_id Units: alpha-numeric Description: sample identification: WBC=whole body clearance expt.; WBF=whole body fluorescence on collection
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20863.rdf Name: time_sample Units: minutes Description: time of sampling for pigment content after collection; decline of pigment content with time was used to calculate time to clear the gut of pigment.
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20864.rdf Name: pigment_content Units: micrograms total chl/grams wet weight Description: pigment content
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20865.rdf Name: stage_id Units: unknown Description: stage development index of larvae in sample (furcilia = F1-6 = 1-6, juvenile = J=7)
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20866.rdf Name: wet_weight Units: mg Description: average wet weight/larvae in sample
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20874.rdf Name: lat Units: decimal degrees Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20875.rdf Name: lon Units: decimal degrees Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20876.rdf Name: day_local Units: unknown Description: day of month, local time
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20877.rdf Name: month_local Units: unknown Description: month, local time
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20878.rdf Name: time_local Units: unknown Description: time of day, local time, using 2400 clock format
http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/20879.rdf Name: yrday_local Units: unknown Description: local day and decimal time, as 326.5 for the 326th day of the year, or November 22 at 1200 hours (noon)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p>Using SCUBA techniques allowed us to collect larval krill as close as possible to their in situ condition. Larval krill were collected for time-based experimentation at the dive hole, for shipboard experiments and preserved for later analysis. Samples of the micro-zooplankton community were sampled with suction samplers to gain a better understanding of food available to the larvae relative to their distribution under the ice. In addition, at one of the process stations we were able to deploy drift nets through the dive holes to compare day/night differences in the zooplankton community at depths of 1 m and 10 m below the ice-water interface. <a href="http://www.ccpo.odu.edu/Research/globec/main_cruises02/lmg0205/report_lmg0205.pdf" target="_blank"><em>(from cruise report LMG0205)</em></a></p>

<p>We collected enough krill for 12 Instantaneous Growth Rate (IGR) experiments, 15 collections for whole body fluorescence experiments (WBF), 11 collections for whole body clearance experiments (WBC), and 9 collections for condition factor. Measurements of length and stage frequency of the dive and net krill collections were done routinely. <a href="http://www.ccpo.odu.edu/Research/globec/main_cruises02/lmg0205/report_lmg0205.pdf" target="_blank"><em>(from cruise report LMG0205)</em></a></p><p><strong>Associated datasets:</strong><br /><a href="http://globec.whoi.edu/jg/serv/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_sum.html0%7Bdir=globec.whoi.edu/jg/dir/globec/soglobec/,info=globec.whoi.edu/jg/info/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_sum%7D">larval_krill_sum - summary of experiments</a><br /><a href="http://globec.whoi.edu/jg/serv/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_cf.html0%7Bdir=globec.whoi.edu/jg/dir/globec/soglobec/,info=globec.whoi.edu/jg/info/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_cf%7D">larval_krill_cf - condition factor, C:N ratio</a><br /><a href="http://globec.whoi.edu/jg/serv/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_gr.html0%7Bdir=globec.whoi.edu/jg/dir/globec/soglobec/,info=globec.whoi.edu/jg/info/globec/soglobec/larval_krill_gr%7D">larval_krill_gr - growth study</a></p>

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: Hand-net Instrument Name: Hand-held plankton net Instrument Short Name:Hand-net Instrument Description: A Hand-held plankton net is a net like a butterfly net only with a standard 333 micron mesh often used by SCUBA divers or from a dock. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/22/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: SCUBA Instrument Name: Manual Biota Sampler Instrument Short Name:Manual Instrument Description: Manual Biota Sampler indicates that a sample was collected in situ by a person, possibly using a hand-held collection device such as a jar, a net or their hands. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/90/
